topic.title: WebTorrent Brings BitTorrent to the Web, Impresses Netflix
topic.body:
BitTorrent currently transfers petabytes of data across the Internet every month, but with the shift to online streaming it's losing prominence. Stanford University graduate Feross Aboukhadijeh is bridging this gap with WebTorrent and has already piqued the interest of Netflix, other tech companies, and many enthusiastic developers.

https://torrentfreak.com/webtorrent-brings-bittorrent-to-the-web-impresses-netflix-151213/

topic.title: Problem with ZeroSearch?
topic.body:
For me it shows `Currently indexing 0 sites`

Can anyone confirm if it's just me?

topic.title: Forbidden Media referrer error
topic.body:
Opening [this](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1QLLPpowM6BWxKYKops1WkCafuFPhFBnAx/muja.asc) through a link [here](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1AyL9MfHbV8nxPBmZpocuVZ6d2JixUPTdv/?Post:9:Internet+Killswitch+Engaged+%28Again+%29#Comments) caused this error. 

Accessing the address from a new tab (not clicking the link) works fine. Anyone knows what's up?

Edit: the link doesn't work here either, is this just me?

topic.title: Invalid private key for ZeroMail
topic.body:
I get this whenever I try to send any emails:

> Site:1MaiL5..Ju27 data/users/17i7Y7r8nTaCfLbCAuaKyc4R5BbKZYU2Hr/content.json: Include too large 30999 > 30000
> Site:1MaiL5..Ju27 Sign failed: Invalid content

and

`Content sign failed: invalid private key.` in the UI.

Anyone knows what's up?

topic.title: How does P2P news flow work?
Chimera Ransomware uses a Peer-To-Peer Decryption Service (BitMessage)
What podcasts (if any) do you listen to?
topic.body: Alternatively, what podcasts do you recommend people to listen to?

topic.title: Is it possible to limit posts per page on a zeroblog clone?
How many site addresses are possible?
topic.body: Are there 2^160 possible sites, the same as bitcoin addresses?

topic.title: What email provider would you recommend as the (apparently) most secure?
What cloud storage service do you use?

2_16iYwD5U2fNoS22p6447J7992iL3DHjSHY.body: If someone managed to make it work and then the error (`TorManager Tor controller connect error: [Errno 111] Connection refused`) came back, using `sudo /etc/init.d/tor restart` again fixed it for me.

Deleting the site did not fix the problem.

This is way better. Thanks!

3_168qV1Xxp2EyszrzdECLUwXrn9wGYjDdar.body:
> [zozon](#comment_31_1QBLGLcgKfcpfLmiDYuDzUKVXFfmTAew55): made a test site does it count?

sure!

> [ekaterina](#comment_14_1Mk5sVKeCrwMc3wSD11jM7DZTiqF5D9BaD): I worked through the tutorial on ZeroBlog to learn how to create sites for ZeroNet, and instead of creating yet another chat I slightly changed the code from the tutorial and created the site ZeroQuotes, which lets you submit quotes from famous (or fictional) people and browse quotes submitted by other users: http://127.0.0.1:43110/1NJyPoPpL8At17T6G7A1qHVQdqZDBmXcLT
> I've also started a blog where I'll update my progress on developing sites for ZeroNet: http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Kp5xdjQyrPth5mEJsn6NDBKZxcaeYz86N

Very nice!
A blog featuring street art delivered through **IPFS**. http://127.0.0.1:43110/18pRWVHHojR2DjfYQvuLe3GBtB1W32Hwbb

> [ow](#comment_18_13KqD3BoaRMudEG5QU2fnGLkSVx8qDXKof): Am I understanding this right? Someone has the domain and server what is running IPFS and that is the site that is the third party hosting the content. It is not delivered through IPFS to the users, it is delivered to the server through IPFS but then is forward to the users. Correct?
> This server and domain are a man in the middle, yeah? Probably a good server for now, but still a eavesdropper, unlike the actual IPFS protocol design?

[ipfs.pics](https://ipfs.pics/), different from the [ipfs.io](https://ipfs.io/) gateway, keeps a copy of the image locally, which should decrease the loading time without relying only on a central server. 

It's free software, so I don't have a problem with this, but you are right, it IS a mitm.

I think I'd rather use the local version, though.

[Public gateway](https://ipfs.io/ipfs/QmYoYK7LcjALwCa8ZXYSgGJRSmav4SGyrfRFLQq8ML2K9x), [local](http://127.0.0.1:8080/ipfs/QmYoYK7LcjALwCa8ZXYSgGJRSmav4SGyrfRFLQq8ML2K9x) and [ipfs.pics](https://ipfs.pics/ipfs/QmYoYK7LcjALwCa8ZXYSgGJRSmav4SGyrfRFLQq8ML2K9x)

> [muja](#comment_13_17i7Y7r8nTaCfLbCAuaKyc4R5BbKZYU2Hr): 
> I think I'd rather use the local version, though.

Now the [site](http://127.0.0.1:43110/18pRWVHHojR2DjfYQvuLe3GBtB1W32Hwbb) uses ipfs.io and I created [another](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1L8ujYEH24bg7QTJaqe9h6LEi5GQxkvhiG) one that uses the local address.

> [nofish](#comment_246_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): Tor browser denies canvas operations that required to dynamically generate images. (The opener present error will be fixed, i'm currently working on it)

The fix came. Nice workaround, works great.
Checkout [DAN](http://127.0.0.1:43110/183hZtmtXXB3vxZTn3WYbjVWtAsoVEtRXN/?Post:1:Welcome+to+the+Deavmi+Archive+Network!). User @Deavmi published forums for different subjects tech-related.

> [lukipuki](#comment_4_1CMYxdit4qq9QGk9DYRu2ruRPd2YDGckH8): I am thinking about adding some (really) huge high quality images as well, but I am not sure about it yet.

If you add `"optional": "(img)",` to your content.json file, then the user will only download the images they "need". So if someone gets a link to [this](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1HzKesHsWG3N96CfW9eC2aL9VKY7EDm2Zj/?Post:21:algorithmic_species) post they will only download those pictures (and the rest of the page), which makes the loading faster. 

[Here](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ReactionGIFs/blob/master/content.json#L1796)'s an example.

> [lukipuki](#comment_5_1CMYxdit4qq9QGk9DYRu2ruRPd2YDGckH8): where do I have to add this ( "optional": "(img)", ) ?

You can put it bellow `"modified": 1455899844.127144,` in your content.json file. Don't forget to sign and publish.

I finally made a blog. So far I have two posts showing some scripts of mine, that's probably what I'll keep sharing there from time to time. [Here](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1QLLPpowM6BWxKYKops1WkCafuFPhFBnAx).

10_1PvAyLAB5H1JKbiFjx95ZJXrNJVyWxs5Hf.body: Can't wait for the "Github-like project hosting" that was announced [here](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Blog.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post:70:The+first+year+of+ZeroNet).

> [nofish](#comment_259_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): The "Github-like project hosting" was referenced as webui, you can already host git repositories on zeronet: just copy your .git directory and sign/publish it.

I can't find the proposal on github, is there an issue there? I understand if it's not a priority though.

11_1PvAyLAB5H1JKbiFjx95ZJXrNJVyWxs5Hf.body:
> [o4zw5vmpoz5hz78z](#comment_84_1KTjPe9MxoYkcXj78GuZgCcj3R3f3Twh7r): yeah i also thought about that i guess we need some kind of version management at some point

I suggest using git in the site folder and add "~~optional~~ **ignore**": "(.git*)" to the content.json file. If someone gets your private key you are pretty much screwed already, but this would keep your data so that you could do something about it.

1_15y72LFjQ4ymUTnkJP6CC7r73R5uoePgFW.body:
> [bbtuxi](#comment_4_15y72LFjQ4ymUTnkJP6CC7r73R5uoePgFW): ach ist doch kacke... viel zu kompliziert.....

Too hard? Was that what you said?

Here are the steps:

python zeronet.py siteCreate (**Creates the site**)
python zeronet.py siteSign **Site Address Here** (_"Saves" the changes_)
python zeronet.py sitePublish **Site Address Here** (_Sends the changes_)

12_1PvAyLAB5H1JKbiFjx95ZJXrNJVyWxs5Hf.body:
> [o4zw5vmpoz5hz78z](#comment_89_1KTjPe9MxoYkcXj78GuZgCcj3R3f3Twh7r): yes! and pls put the wiki also into zeronet.

I made a page using [Strapdown](http://strapdownjs.com/) but it would need to be updated manually and all pages would need to be made into HTML ones. It's doable though. [Here](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1jVJjppSiP1g7XEocHd3UB5Yb5qAfQyMy/faq.html) it is.

> [o4zw5vmpoz5hz78z](#comment_91_1KTjPe9MxoYkcXj78GuZgCcj3R3f3Twh7r): if you could do a script for that downloading the markdown file and compiling it and publishing to zeronet it would not be a problem to run it once a day or week
> i see https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/Documentation is what i want

I don't know how to add text inside the `<xmp></xmp>` tag with a command, any ideas?
If not we'll need a js renderer or something that converts in the browser. Maybe there are other ways to do it. 

The script would pull the repository, _convert the files_, sign and publish. I would call it `0docs.sh`.

> [nofish](#comment_273_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): The Readthedocs.org site using http://www.mkdocs.org/ to generate the html files, so you can also use it and you will get the exact same look.

Cool. I think it worked. [Here](http://127.0.0.1:43110/17Kom2G5qNDc6NaQwv445h1gFzxkY3ZtZe).

A few problems: 

- There's the `Forbidden: Opener present.` error whenever a new page is requested.
- ~~Public proxies [zero.pags](http://zero.pags.to:43110/17Kom2G5qNDc6NaQwv445h1gFzxkY3ZtZe) and [bit.no](http://bit.no.com:43110/17Kom2G5qNDc6NaQwv445h1gFzxkY3ZtZe) failed to download the content.json file. [Classcoder](https://zeronet.classcoder.com/17Kom2G5qNDc6NaQwv445h1gFzxkY3ZtZe) works fine.~~ They're all working now.

> [nofish](#comment_277_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): Nice, the only problem I see is the loading screen is displayed every time when clicking on a sub-page link, I will look into it tomorrow.

Thank you :)

And here's the script I will use to update the site, suggestions are welcome:

**0docs.sh**
```
#!/bin/bash

cd /path/Documentation
git pull origin master
mkdocs build --clean
cp -ur site/* /path/zeronet/data/17Kom2G5qNDc6NaQwv445h1gFzxkY3ZtZe/

cd /path/zeronet
python zeronet.py siteSign 17Kom2G5qNDc6NaQwv445h1gFzxkY3ZtZe
python zeronet.py sitePublish 17Kom2G5qNDc6NaQwv445h1gFzxkY3ZtZe
```

1_154jAWx5PDRmvF4txGHo4Edw1BpduhDyvw.body:
> [oracle](#comment_142_1ED3Ho3kmzaKiECtyuqSjDpoE47rKuXeP): 

While I understand your point, I have to disagree. Less than one year ago I was you; I "hated" coding and programming languages mostly because I couldn't understand it. After a series of fortunate accidents, I ended up learning more and more and now I fucking love it!

It's very easy (and understandable) to think that things that don't look simple are hard, but if you look close enough, you'll start to see that it's very logical and might end up liking it.

For instance, take a look at [this](https://guides.github.com/features/mastering-markdown/) guide to markdown. You'll see how simple and powerful it is.

You might still prefer a CMS, and that's ok, but the current state of zeronet is in no way difficult, you just need to look closer :)

I would gladly help you with whatever issues you come up with (and surely more experienced people would as well) but I strongly believe that if you change your mindset to one of curiosity instead of disregarding it as hard, I'm sure that you'll eventually start to like it. After all, programming is the backbone of the twenty first century.

> [kaffie](#comment_53_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): 

>I think you're missing the point. 

I don't see it that way. I think that you described the outcomes of what I described. I wrote about how people might get intimidated with programming and then the outcome is what you described; reddit moderators, myspace.

> However, I do see this as an opportunity to educate people on how stuff actually works, and get them digging into code and learning about how websites work, rather than continue to rely on buttons.

I agree. I even said as much here "but if you look close enough, you'll start to see that it's very logical and might end up liking it."

> All that being said, I love markdown. It's fantastic. It should honestly be a standard.

Agreed!

I think my tone was different. I focused on how to change a mindset, while you showed the result of the current mindset. I don't think we disagreed on this. Please correct me if I'm wrong.  :)

1_13qeq1z87R1kQWDZUQYm3y7tDCLimnhfvS.body:
I think that, at least for now, we should be the ones in charge of choosing and showing a license. See [this](http://127.0.0.1:43110/17pTf9tzLGxVQnRKGhg1M85DCXJ7YXPdv9) site for example. Even a small text line would be enough. 

With time we could send a pull request for a key on the content.json file like `"license": "GPL v3",` but most people simply don't care. And since ZeroNet is licensed with GPL, can't we assume that all sites derived from it (clones, for example) are GPL-licensed as well?

1_17oYQdLkvyzEVPH3hXRtK3ru4FLNKZUD3b.body:
> [eventi](#comment_9_1DcDDitsjFJohvwonPmpibRChmA7uGxqL7): 
> Ideally I'd like to see a mechanism to selectively block certain identified users at the viewer's discression.  It doesn't seem too hard to do (in ZeroTalk for example)

This doesn't seem hard at all. We probably could do it today (with a few errors, probably). I imagine a script that would keep deleting the data/*/data/users/17i7Y7r8nTaCfLbCAuaKyc4R5BbKZYU2Hr/ folder (my user's folder). This would probably remove that user from your feed. The problem is that (I think) zeronet would keep downloading it. Not sure how that can be fixed without a built-in solution.

1_13AvYD3hX888Ey6y8kFEce3Ak8hVNLcdrg.body:
Yes! 

Just move your zeronet folder to another directory. If you downloaded the ZeroNet Bundle, don't forget the Python folder.

4_1LRrd96P7FiTcsyNXVzPM5jtpQoH1B4gYf.body:
> [ekaterina](#comment_87_1Mk5sVKeCrwMc3wSD11jM7DZTiqF5D9BaD): 
> maybe a system where you hold onto a friend's private key and he to yours could work, so you always let your friend sign your updates and deny that such a deal with a friend exists if asked.

This could solve most of these problems. I think a good way to do it would be the [signers_sign](https://zeronet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/site_development/content_json/#signers_sign) and [signs_required](https://zeronet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/site_development/content_json/#signs_required) keys that (if I understood right) allows you to have more than one signing key and a required number of signs.

So, you allow three signers and require two, one of them stays with your friend, one with you and one is kept hidden in a different manner, just in case.

**Edit:** looking closer I don't think that's how it works, I'm making some tests.

16_14XxpXNGMLsyeQxikacrbQnAFXVyhN5Ngx.body:
> [noiamo](#comment_39_14XxpXNGMLsyeQxikacrbQnAFXVyhN5Ngx): I was wondering how to make a site password accessible not my UI server

Currently it's not possible. It has been proposed [here](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/62). You can donate for it [here](https://zeronet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/help_zeronet/donate/#private-sites).

1_1PRtPMsAohGekTGBAqKEZG1V8ZPX4iY2gW.body:
With Tor Always:
```
Connected: 2  Connectable: 998
Onion: 554    Total: 998
```

But the number is kind of irrelevant. The important part is being able to receive and publish changes to some of those peers and then those will propagate it further. It's safe to assume that the actual number is bigger.

2_1KSNSPNM5FTUwPJeyyHrLXek1dsumpnFm1.body:
> [zeroworld](#comment_4_1KSNSPNM5FTUwPJeyyHrLXek1dsumpnFm1): I did from the web interface, where can I find my private key?

If you cloned your site then it's on your data/users.json file. Just search for the site address and the private key will show up bellow it.

The web interface should still work. Just sign and publish again and try opening your site with a proxy. Take a look at [ZeroProxies](http://127.0.0.1:43110/14y3fN1A214HYdKe5f6WnQdfT3PdKLSAJo).

5_15NScazvsCHNmiXi6o6nvaMiwjeJYizgZQ.body:
> [musickiller](#comment_99_15NScazvsCHNmiXi6o6nvaMiwjeJYizgZQ): thanks!
> But it only allow simple one line notes. I hope to find something to replace Google Keep (at least, at best - to replace Evernote).
> I guess someone will make it sooner or later =)

Another way is to make a [Nullpaste](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1MgHVPCE1ve6QfKrgsqCURzRj72HrRWioz) clone and never publish its address. So it will never leave your computer and if Nullpaste gets compromised an attacker wouldn't be able to delete your notes and/or force the site to publish your unencrypted content when you access it.

Bonus points if you encrypt all notes/pastes. See also this [post](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1C5P1EcTZA6FDEg4w6SacfPjvSDCWmzeyt/?Post:9:Unique+Usage+for+a+ZeroTalk+Fork) by cryptonbits.

Looking forward to ekaterina's site.

1_19qsuxKBkNZWYft3epWgn6u3gG82sQHs6n.body: It has been proposed already, take a look at the GitHub issue: https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/388.

1_1By85xCDz7VyZEq9WjmhtbNaPKimQwhPLp.body:
> But if I post It, I suppose, It is considered like "stealing"!

It would not be stealing since when you copy something you make two out of one and in most countries "stealing" is subtraction of other's possession. It might, however, be copyright infringement. Sadly it will depend on your country and also the country of the creator of the article.

But to be honest, the person probably will never know and if they did, your intention (non-commercial distribution to preserve "vanishing") would not trigger legal reaction from them, since it would also cost them money. They probably wouldn't care.

I'd say do it! If you're not using it for commercial reasons then I think there's absolutely nothing wrong with it. Consider, as Erkan said, archive.org's [Way Back Machine](https://archive.org/web/) to save that article with no trouble and probably for a lot of time.

4_1By85xCDz7VyZEq9WjmhtbNaPKimQwhPLp.body:
Do you use Linux? (or Unix-like)

If your machine is insecure when you're away, then the best option would be disk encryption and password login. If that's not possible (shared computer or whatever) then you can encrypt only your user.

Here's a quick script adapted from [here](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1QLLPpowM6BWxKYKops1WkCafuFPhFBnAx/?Post:4:Changing+and+encrypting+ZeroIds):

`saver.sh`
```bash
mkdir -p /tmp/zeronet/users/$1 > /dev/null 2>&1
cp /path/to/zeronet/data/users.json /tmp/zeronet/users/$1/users.json
shred -u /path/to/zeronet/data/users.json
cp /path/to/zeronet/data/sites.json /tmp/zeronet/users/$1/sites.json
shred -u /path/to/zeronet/data/sites.json
cd /tmp/zeronet/users
zip -rq $1.zip $1/ > /dev/null 2>&1
gpg --yes -r SomeKey -o /home/muja/backups/zeronet/users/$1.zip.asc -aes /tmp/zeronet/users/$1.zip
shred -u $1.zip
rm -rf $1/
```

Run it like `saver.sh muja` to encrypt and delete the user *muja*. Decrypting should be easier and can also be automated.

14_1CMjV2r4EBpFt8VCcWWZKDysZXPcPExRNN.body:
Great initiative! You should learn a bit about [optional files](http://127.0.0.1:43110/138R53t3ZW7KDfSfxVpWUsMXgwUnsDNXLP/?Page:optional-files) if you plan on adding a lot of files. Check the examples.

Also, md5 and sha1 are not ideal for security/integrity. You should try sha2 instead.

> [zeroexef](#comment_16_1CSc14JKdGAQJfQsfCLrduhB6zU4oEMwBf): Awesome. I didn't know about the optional files. I'll look into that tomorrow. As for the hash,  that's a good idea. We might include md5 and sha256 because I know it can be hard to find sha256 on windows machines.  
> On that same note, does anybody know a good file hasher for windows? My preliminary search turned up HashTab, which seems pretty good.

I'm not on Windows but I would use something like [Quick Hash](https://sourceforge.net/projects/quickhash/) because it's open source. But HashTab seems pretty good indeed.
